oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Roots below one meters depth are important for nitrate uptake by annual crops
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Kristensen, Hanne L.
Thorup-Kristensen, Kristian
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nutrient turnover
Crop combinations and interactions
Vegetables
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The root depths of annual crops vary from 0.2 m to more than 2 m depending on root growth rate and length of growing season. However, studies of root growth and N uptake are often restricted to a depth of 1 m or less, as root biomass is assumed to be negligible below this depth. We have studied the importance of root growth and N uptake to a depth of 2.5 m in fully grown field vegetables and cover crops by use of minirhizotrons and deep point placement of 15N. Deep rooted crucifereous crops were found to have high root densities to a depth of 1.5-2 m and high 15N uptake to this depth. The work shows that knowledge of the interactions between root growth and soil N below a depth of 1 m are important to understand crop N uptake and nitrate leaching from agro-ecosystems.
